set.title: The Alphora Dataphor Combined Help Collection

abstract.para: The Alphora Dataphor Combined Help Collection contains the documentation for the Alphora Dataphor Toolset which includes both the Alphora Dataphor Data Access Engine (DAE) and the Alphora Dataphor Frontend.

The Alphora Dataphor toolset is a Database Application Development Framework that automates many of the tasks involved in the creation and maintenance of database applications. The Dataphor Data Access Engine provides a logical abstraction for communication with database management systems (DBMS), while the Dataphor Frontend provides a logical abstraction of user interface definitions. Together these technologies form the foundation for the next generation of database applications.

This help collection is organized as follows:
User's Guide
Provides a high-level introduction to the Dataphor toolset, as well as several tutorials, and information on using the various utilities that come with the Dataphor product such as Dataphoria and the DAE Service.
DAE Developer's Guide
Provides detailed coverage of the Dataphor Data Access Engine including a D4 language guide and information on using and extending the DAE.
Frontend Developer's Guide
Provides detailed documentation for using the Dataphor Frontend to develop applications in the Automated Application Development paradigm.
DAC Developer's Guide
Provides documentation for using the Dataphor Data Access Components in a classic Rapid Application Development paradigm.

The following links may be used to gain a quick overview of Dataphor product features:
Dataphor Introduction
D4 Language Guide
The Relational Model of Data
The Dataphor Data Access Engine (DAE) as a Database Management System
The DAE as a Data Access Engine
D4 Compared wtih SQL
Storage Integration

set.book:
Dataphor User's Guide
The Dataphor User's Guide provides the reader with the information necessary to begin using Dataphor. The Guide provides an overview of the motivation behind Dataphor, introduces the Dataphor technology, then provides several tutorials. &UsersGuideIntro; &UsersGuidePartI; &UsersGuidePartII; &Glossary;

Dataphor Frontend Developers Guide
The Frontend Developer’s Guide focuses on the user interface and interaction capabilities of the toolset. It includes a detailed view of the server and client architectures, an analysis of the mechanisms involved in application automation, as well as complete reference and extensibility information. &FrontendDevGuideIntro; &FrontendDevGuidePartI; &FrontendDevGuidePartII;
Frontend ReferenceFrontend Reference
This part provides detailed reference information for the Dataphor Frontend.
DIL ReferenceDataphor user Interface Language ReferenceDataphor user Interface Language Overview of DIL
DIL is an XML application tightly integrated with the Frontend Client. Each element tag of DIL represents a node that is defined in a Frontend Client. So, when you see a <checkbox ... > tag in an interface document you know that the client has a checkbox node defined to render the DIL element. Properties in the client nodes which may be set are represented as element attributes in DIL. The values attached to the attributes are converted to the appropriate type and assigned to the properties of the client node.
When a DIL element is derived rather than built by hand, the Derivation engine uses the metadata described in Derivation Reference to generate attributes and values for the client.
Nearly every DIL element has a bop:name attribute. This is the name used to resolve references to other elements, such as a reference to a source element. Empty Interface
The following is an empty Interface element. The interface may contain exactly one Element node and several action, source, and other non-element nodes. The Designer enforces the rules of ownership/parenthood in DIL. If you have questions about whether a node can appear in a specific location, try out the Designer. <interface xmlns:bop='www.alphora.com/schemas/bop' text='form name goes here' mainsource='MainSourceName goes here' >
</interface>
The xmlns:bop declaration provides several services used in converting DIL from a text format to an interactive form. The text attribute provides the title used on the form. The mainsource attribute provides a global alias to a source defined in the body of the interface. See the appropriate interface class (listed in the see also section) for more information about the interface. Keyboard Accelerators
The text/title of nodes may include accelerator hints marked by an ampersand ("&"), but these are considered optional by the client. The Windows client will allocate the requested accelerator hint if available, or assign its own if not available. The Web client currently strips off accelerators. Designer Toolbox
The list of core elements in the toolbox comes from the nodetype.dnt file.
If you extend DIL by adding controls and their corresponding Frontend Nodes, you must list the new nodes in the nodetype.dnt file to expose them for use in the Designer.
If you would like to assign an icon to a Frontend Node that you create, use the DesignerImageAttribute to select an image form the list of images used by the Designer. &DILReference;
Basic Object Persistence (BOP)
This chapter contains information about the classes implementing Dataphor BOP. &BOP;
Common Nodes
This chapter contains information about the Frontend nodes common to the Windows and Web clients. &FrontendClient;&FrontendClientReporting;
Windows Nodes
This chapter contains information about the Frontend nodes specific to the Windows Client. &FrontendClientWindows;
Web Nodes
This chapter contains information about the Frontend nodes specific to the Web client. &FrontendClientWeb;
Frontend Server
This chapter contains information about the Frontend Server. &FrontendServer;
Requests
This section contains information about the Frontend requests. &FrontendServerRequestTypes;&DerivationReference;
